markdownRemark.html:
First off, Phoenix LiveView has been a dream to work with so far. I really recommend looking at it for your next web application.

One of the things I love about LiveView is that it enables me to consolidate some of common front-end logic into the backend, where the source of truth belongs. A great example is a form, especially long-running or multi-step forms.

Let me show you what I mean.

There’s a couple of components you see in here:

  • DatePicker (LiveView)
  • Vue-mounted TipTap WYSIWYG editor (LiveView, and also mounts a Vue component)
  • Recurrence component (hidden behind a checkbox, not demoed)

I coded this form twice.

The Ugly Way

First, I coded it all with a single LiveView. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted on the form, but eventually this LiveView was an ugly 1000-line horror that managed state in multiple places like the changeset and the socket. It was pretty terrible. There has to be a better way. It’s a single <form> that handled all the attributes, and each step was simply hidden until you hit “next”.
